title: Explore user problems and provide UX improvement recommendations for making modes more usable

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Modes and the ability to customize them is a powerful feature in VS Code. How can we further improve the discoverability and utility of the feature? Specifically: 
- How can we make sure new users trying chat can be successful without having to learn about modes first?
- How can we suggest when users should switch or customize modes? 
- How can we make customizing modes easier?

title: Feature Request: Sync prompt files (chat mode instructions) across profiles and machines via Settings Sync

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Currently, prompt files, custom instructions and chat modes, stored in profile-specific user data directories are profile centric and are not included in VS Code's Settings Sync. This means users cannot access their custom chat instructions across different profiles or machines, limiting portability and productivity for those who rely on personalized chat experiences.

### Expected Behavior
- Prompt files and chat mode instructions should be synced across all profiles and machines when Settings Sync is enabled.
- Users should be able to access, edit, and use their custom prompts regardless of which profile or device they are using.

### Actual Behavior
- Switching profiles or machines results in loss of access to custom instructions unless manually copied.
- 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a custom prompt file in a profile. 
2. Enable Settings Sync and sign in on another machine or profile.
3. Observe that prompt files are not available on the new environment.

Please consider adding prompt file sync to Settings Sync to enhance the chat experience across profiles and devices.

title: Transparently render the actual discount used in auto

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

body:
Today we show Variable as a multiplier for Auto. We should improve this to check if all models in Auto have the same discount, and if yes to render it more prominently. For example, writing `0.9x`, or rendering `10%` discount.

The current hover message is not discoverable enough and wrongly always says 0-1x. While it should be SKU dependandt.


fyi @joaomoreno @pierceboggan @jo-oikawa

title: Ability to run client experiments to change what model Auto is resolved to

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

body:
Right now CAPI tells VS Code what models are available for Auto. And it also sends a `selected_model` - as a way to prefer a model.
VS Code then picks up the `selected_model`, and ignores all the other Auto models.

We need to build the capability in VS Code side to be able to more dynamically chose between all the Auto models. And that an ExP can influence this choice. This way we will be able to run informed experiments and see what is the effect of resolving different models in Auto.

title: Auto model fetching is slowing down first request by ~150ms (in Europe)

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

body:
Right now we fetch the list of Auto models on first request. The issue is that this takes 150ms (and sometimes 1000ms+) in Europe.

We should:
- [ ] Add telemetry so we can measure how fast the fetching of Auto model is
- [ ] Consider if we could fetch models at a different time. E.g. on open of Chat view

title: Disable Auto when preview features are disabled via GH policy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

body:
We are hearing strong feedback from the field team that enterprises want a way to disable Auto while they audit it.

We already have an enterprise policy from GH about disabling preview features.
I suggest that we simply do not show Auto if Preview features are disabled.

The goal is to keep Auto in preview in September, and then in October mark it as GA (if all goes as planned).

Currently, in agent mode, it's only possible to accept or reject entire hunks. It would be good to be able to select a few lines (especially from the beginning/end of the hunk) and accept only those.

title: Copilot spawns new terminals for CLI commands causing failed requests
body:
I am using copilot in agent mode with Claude Sonnet 4 (pls see all specs below). The problem I have is that almost every time the agent needs to execute a CLI command, it spawns a new terminal in VS Code. Many commands require path awareness to execute properly, but since the new terminal opens in the root of the project, the command fails.

I added explicit instructions to the agent **NOT** to spawn new terminals unless allowed, but the behavior persists. The agent apologizes for the issue but continues to do it.

I don't recall this issue being present in the past, but since I upgraded to copilot pro I am using copilot a lot more and with different models.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.3
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup)
- OS Version: 24H2 (OS Build 26120.5790) - Insiders 
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs: Apologies in advance, I don't know how to export logs that do not have personal information or code snippets. The following lines are heavily edited
<details>
<summary>Logs begin</summary>

### userRequest
~~~md
From now on, please follow these rules for terminal use
```
Terminal usage rules
- When executing `dotnet` commands in the terminal, include the architecture (e.g., x64) whenever possible
- Reuse your own terminals. This avoids running commands and finding out that you are not in the expected path, for example.
- When not sure whether current terminal can be reused, ask the user to select the proper terminal or approve starting a new one.
```
They are also included in `agent-instructions.md`
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
Understood! I'll follow those terminal usage rules from now on. Let me reuse the existing terminal that has the correct build path and find the executable:
🛠️ get_terminal_output (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "id": "19712"
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
Let me check which terminals are available and reuse the appropriate one:
🛠️ run_in_terminal (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "explanation": "Finding the build output location using the existing terminal from myApp directory",
  "command": "ls -la myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/",
  "isBackground": false
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
PS D:\source\myApp> ls -la myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/
Get-ChildItem: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'la'.


Command exited with code 1
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~



## Response
### Assistant
~~~md
Let me use the correct PowerShell command: 
🛠️ run_in_terminal (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "explanation": "Finding the build output location in the correct directory",
  "command": "Get-ChildItem myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/",
  "isBackground": false
}
~~~


### [OTHER COMMANDS HERE]

### userRequest
~~~md
You are not following instructions. Do not spawn new terminals unless explicitly allowed

copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
You're absolutely right, I apologize for not following the terminal usage rules. I should have reused the existing terminal ID `23484` instead of spawning a new one. 

Let me check the status of the application using the existing terminal:
🛠️ get_terminal_output (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "id": "23484"
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
I need to use the correct existing terminal. Let me check the available terminal that was used for the build:
🛠️ get_terminal_output (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "id": "27744"
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~



## Response
### Assistant
~~~md
I apologize for the confusion with terminal IDs. Following the rules, since I'm not sure which terminal can be reused, I should ask you: 

**May I please use an existing terminal or do you approve starting a new one to check the application status?**

I will not create any new terminals without your explicit permission, as per the agent instructions you've highlighted.
~~~

### [OTHER COMMANDS HERE]

Logs End
</details>

New terminals continue to be spawned.



## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create WinUI 3 (but I think any framework/language will do the same) project in agent mode.
2. Provide instructions, in `docs\copilot\agent-instructions.md`. Provide app PRD in `docs\copilot\prd.md`
3. Include specific instructions not to spawn new terminals and instead reuse existing one unless necessary
4. Generate app, interact normally.
5. Ask Agent to fix or expand functionality that requires running command line commands (dotnet, Get-ChildItem, cd, etc.)
6. As multiple commands are executed, the agent expects to be in a certain path, but since a new terminal is spawned, the command is executed in the wrong path, resulting in failed and repeated premium requests.

title: Clear the chat panel with the number of file changes after all changes have been accepted
body: Every time the agent updates a file, it gets added to this panel: If there's 10 files, it will take up a large area in the sidebar. If the terminal is also open in the bottom, the space left of the chat text can get quite small. It would make sense to clear these files once their changes have been accepted. The current workaround is to start a new chat, which isn't always desirable.

title: Improve Problem Selection and Search in GitHub Copilot Context Addition
body:
This PR enhances the GitHub Copilot context addition feature for problems by adding two key improvements that streamline the developer workflow:

## 🎯 **Problem Prioritization**

Problems from the currently open file now appear at the top of the selection list, making it much easier to find relevant issues when working with multiple files. The active file is clearly marked with a "(current file)" indicator in the separator label.

**Before:**
```
Problems...
├── file1.ts
│   └── Error: Missing semicolon
├── file2.js  
│   └── Warning: Unused variable
└── myCurrentFile.ts
    └── Error: Type mismatch
```

**After:**
```
Problems...
├── myCurrentFile.ts (current file)
│   └── Error: Type mismatch
├── file1.ts
│   └── Error: Missing semicolon
└── file2.js
    └── Warning: Unused variable
```

## 🔍 **Search Functionality**

Users can now filter problems by typing file names or paths directly in the picker. The search is case-insensitive and matches both file basenames and relative paths.

**Examples:**
- Type `".ts"` → Shows only TypeScript files
- Type `"src"` → Shows only files in src directory  
- Type `"spec"` → Shows only test spec files
- Type `"myfile"` → Shows files containing "myfile" in name or path

## 🔧 **Implementation Details**

- **Minimal Changes**: Enhanced existing `MarkerChatContextPick` class without breaking existing functionality
- **Performance**: Efficient filtering and sorting with no impact on VS Code startup
- **Edge Cases**: Handles scenarios like no active editor, empty problem lists, and special characters gracefully
- **Testing**: Comprehensive unit tests covering prioritization, search filtering, and edge cases

## 📈 **User Benefits**

- **Faster Problem Access**: Current file problems appear first, reducing scroll time
- **Better Search**: Quick filtering by filename reduces time spent browsing
- **Improved Workflow**: Streamlined experience when working with multiple files
- **Backward Compatible**: Existing functionality remains unchanged

The implementation follows established patterns in VS Code (similar to search and SCM chat context features) and uses proper dependency injection with `IEditorService` to access the active editor information.

Fixes #265662.

title: Accept edits before the agent has finished
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

With GitHub Copilot in Agent mode, minutes can pass between a request and a final answer. This breaks productivity and it would be good to be able to start reviewing the changes before the agent has finished. 

This can add complexity because the agent might undo edits, this happens rarely. One way to mitigate it would be to interpret clicking on "Keep" prematurely as a "suggestion" (marking it visually so the user knows they don't have to re-review that hunk). If the agent changes a prematurely kept hunk, it would disregard the user action (the user would still have to review it). Otherwise, it would keep it automatically. The same would happen with "Undo"

title: Support referencing selected file(s) as inputs to MCP Prompt arguments
body:
This PR adds support for easily referencing the currently active file and selected text as inputs to MCP Prompt arguments, addressing the need for streamlined code review workflows.

## Problem

Previously, users working with MCP prompts that required file content as arguments had to manually copy-paste file contents or use the file search functionality. This was particularly cumbersome for code review scenarios where users wanted to reference the currently open file or selected code snippets.

## Solution

Added a new "Active File" section to the MCP prompt argument picker that provides:

1. **Active File option**: Includes the full content of the currently active file
2. **Selected Text option**: Includes only the selected text from the active editor (when text is selected)

## Implementation Details

- Extended `McpPromptArgumentPick` with `ICodeEditorService` and `IEditorService` dependencies
- Added new `activeFile` and `selectedText` action types to the `PickItem` interface
- Created `_activeFileCompletions()` method that dynamically provides active file options
- Added proper handling for the new action types in the argument processing logic
- Included appropriate icons, descriptions, and localization strings

## User Experience

The new functionality appears seamlessly in the existing prompt argument picker UI:

- **Active File** option shows the file path and uses the appropriate file type icon
- **Selected Text** option shows line information and a preview of the selected text
- Both options only appear when relevant (active editor exists, text is selected)
- Maintains the existing workflow while adding convenient shortcuts

This change makes it much easier to create MCP prompts for code review and analysis by providing quick access to currently open file content without manual copy-pasting.

Fixes #252045.

title: Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/265125
Language specific user settings should not override all-languages workspace settings

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In workspace settings checked into the repository, I'll usually specify some settings to take precedence over any of the same setting specified in user settings:

```
{
  "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode"
}
```

Contributing developers however may have the same setting set as a language specific one in their user settings. This will take precedence over the non-specific workspace setting, which is undesirable:

```
{
  "[javascript]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "vscode.typescript-language-features"
  }
}
```

Workarounds:
1. Add language-specific workspace settings for every language used in the project. These can be combined under a single key e.g. `[javascript][typescript]`.
2. Ask contributors to disable such settings.

title: Copilot spawns new terminals for CLI commands when not needed.
body:
**THIS IS NOT A BILLING ISSUE**

I am using copilot in agent mode with Claude Sonnet 4 (pls see all specs below). The problem I have is that almost every time the agent needs to execute a CLI command, it spawns a new terminal in VS Code. Many commands require path awareness to execute properly, but since the new terminal opens in the root of the project, the command fails. This wastes premium requests and time.

I added explicit instructions to the agent **NOT** to spawn new terminals unless allowed, but the behavior persists. The agent apologizes for the issue but continues to do it.

I don't recall this issue being present in the past, but since I upgraded to copilot pro I am using copilot a lot more and with different models.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.3
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2 (user setup)
- OS Version: 24H2 (OS Build 26120.5790) - Insiders 
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude Sonnet 4
- Logs: Apologies in advance, I don't know how to export logs that do not have personal information or code snippets. The following lines are heavily edited
<details>
<summary>Logs begin</summary>

### userRequest
~~~md
From now on, please follow these rules for terminal use
```
Terminal usage rules
- When executing `dotnet` commands in the terminal, include the architecture (e.g., x64) whenever possible
- Reuse your own terminals. This avoids running commands and finding out that you are not in the expected path, for example.
- When not sure whether current terminal can be reused, ask the user to select the proper terminal or approve starting a new one.
```
They are also included in `agent-instructions.md`
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
Understood! I'll follow those terminal usage rules from now on. Let me reuse the existing terminal that has the correct build path and find the executable:
🛠️ get_terminal_output (tooluse_<redacted>) {

}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
Let me check which terminals are available and reuse the appropriate one:
🛠️ run_in_terminal (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "explanation": "Finding the build output location using the existing terminal from myApp directory",
  "command": "ls -la myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/",
  "isBackground": false
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
PS D:\source\myApp> ls -la myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/
Get-ChildItem: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'la'.


Command exited with code 1
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~



## Response
### Assistant
~~~md
Let me use the correct PowerShell command: 
🛠️ run_in_terminal (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "explanation": "Finding the build output location in the correct directory",
  "command": "Get-ChildItem myApp/bin/Debug/net8.0-windows10.0.19041.0/",
  "isBackground": false
}
~~~


### [OTHER COMMANDS HERE]

### userRequest
~~~md
You are not following instructions. Do not spawn new terminals unless explicitly allowed

copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
You're absolutely right, I apologize for not following the terminal usage rules. I should have reused the existing terminal ID `23484` instead of spawning a new one. 

Let me check the status of the application using the existing terminal:
🛠️ get_terminal_output (tooluse_<redacted>) {
  "id": "23484"
}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md
🛠️ tooluse_<redacted>
ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~

### Assistant
~~~md
I need to use the correct existing terminal. Let me check the available terminal that was used for the build:

}
~~~

### Tool
~~~md

ERROR while calling tool: Invalid terminal ID
Please check your input and try again.
copilot_cache_control: {"type":"ephemeral"}
~~~



## Response
### Assistant
~~~md
I apologize for the confusion with terminal IDs. Following the rules, since I'm not sure which terminal can be reused, I should ask you: 

**May I please use an existing terminal or do you approve starting a new one to check the application status?**

I will not create any new terminals without your explicit permission, as per the agent instructions you've highlighted.
~~~

### [OTHER COMMANDS HERE]

Logs End
</details>

New terminals continue to be spawned, wasting requests, resources and time.



## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create WinUI 3 (but I think any framework/language will do the same) project in agent mode.
2. Provide instructions, in `docs\copilot\agent-instructions.md`. Provide app PRD in `docs\copilot\prd.md`
3. Include specific instructions not to spawn new terminals and instead reuse existing one unless necessary
4. Generate app, interact normally.
5. Ask Agent to fix or expand functionality that requires running command line commands (dotnet, Get-ChildItem, cd, etc.)
6. As multiple commands are executed, the agent expects to be in a certain path, but since a new terminal is spawned, the command is executed in the wrong path, resulting in failed and repeated premium requests.

body:

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 22.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Programmatically install MS C/C++ for Visual Studio Code Extension using the following code
```
vscode.commands.executeCommand("workbench.extensions.installExtension", "ms-vscode.cpptools").then(
  () => {
          if (installSuccessMessage) void showInfoHandler(installSuccessMessage);
        },
        (error: Error) => {
          showErrorHandler(error.message);
        });
```
2. After step 1 successfully ended. Check programmatically if the extension is installed or not
```
const ext = vscode.extensions.getExtension("ms-vscode.cpptools");
if (!ext) {
  return false;
}
return true;
```

Expected result: Step 2 returns true, because C/C++ is not only got installed successfully programmatically, it shows up in the installed extension panel.

Actual result: Step 2 returns false, till VSCode is restarted.

title: Fix color picker alpha format for transparent colors
body:
The color picker was incorrectly handling transparent colors when converting them to hex format. When a color like `rgba(0, 0, 0, 0)` (transparent black) was converted to hex, it would become `#000000` instead of the correct `#00000000`, losing the alpha information.

## Root Cause

In `defaultDocumentColorProvider.ts`, the logic for determining whether to use hex or hexA format was:

```typescript
const hex = alpha ? Color.Format.CSS.formatHexA(color) : Color.Format.CSS.formatHex(color);
```

This condition is problematic because:
- When `alpha = 0` (transparent), the condition is falsy, so it uses `formatHex()` → `#000000`
- When `alpha = 1` (opaque), the condition is truthy, so it uses `formatHexA()` → `#000000ff`
- When `alpha = 0.5` (semi-transparent), the condition is truthy, so it uses `formatHexA()` → `#00000080`

The issue was that transparent colors (alpha=0) were treated the same as opaque colors, losing their alpha component.

## Fix

Changed the condition to properly distinguish between opaque and non-opaque colors:

```typescript
const hex = alpha !== 1 ? Color.Format.CSS.formatHexA(color) : Color.Format.CSS.formatHex(color);
```

Now the behavior is:
- When `alpha = 1` (opaque): use `formatHex()` → `#000000` (no alpha needed)
- When `alpha ≠ 1` (transparent or semi-transparent): use `formatHexA()` → `#00000000` or `#00000080`

## Result

- ✅ `rgba(0, 0, 0, 0)` → `#00000000` (transparent black with alpha preserved)
- ✅ `rgba(0, 0, 0, 1)` → `#000000` (opaque black, no unnecessary alpha)
- ✅ `rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)` → `#00000080` (semi-transparent black with alpha)

The same fix was applied to RGB and HSL formats for consistency.

Fixes #256853.

body: The fetch tool currently shows the standard 4 choice UX when fetching a URL: allow now, always allow in this session, always allow in this workspace and always allow: This is too coarse grained since the user often might want to declare to always allow based on the URL or on the domain. I would even argue this to be more useful that the session/workspace/always dimensions. Something like: - Always approve this URL - Always approve URLs from `bing.com` This would be similar to the terminal auto approve, where those dimensions aren't available, but rather allowance based on the terminal commands themselves:

title: Install Visual Studio Code Directly Into the Applications Folder in macOS
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently when we install Visual Studio Code on any version of macOS, it gets downloaded and stays in the downloads folder itself. VS Code would run from this downloads folder and stay right there until the user decides to move it to the applications folder.

The intended behaviour in macOS is to install the applications directly to the applications folder and run applications from there without any requirement of user to move or perform any action for an application to be put into the applications folder.

I do have the knowledge that VS Code is not a direct macOS app but based on electron.js. Still, another application called Discord uses the same technology but installs the application directly into applications folder by downloading a DMG and dragging and dropping it after running.

I request to please look into this issue and have Visual Studio Code directly installed into the applications folder as soon as possible.

title: remove implicit fetch tool URL remembering
body:
this was even flawed since the implementation talked about `alreadyApprovedDomains` when in fact it was the entire URL that was remembered and there was no way to still fetch the URL without always approving it

title: fix: race condition on supported task types
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->

fix #265845

In https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/212163, the `registerSupportedExecutions` was changed so that in web mode, the function doesn't wait for all default task extensions registration before running the task, because in web mode, only the `custom` mode is supported.

However, when there is a remote server, the server will register the support for all task execution types, but later.

A race condition can happen, in which the tasks are parsed before the server reports the supported task executions, leading to a `Warning: shell tasks are unavailable in the current environment.` error.

This PR makes the `registerSupportedExecutions` method wait for all task supported executions in web mode when there is a remote agent.

title: feat: Add session ID to telemetry events for completions provider
body:
- Add sessionId parameter to inlineCompletionAccept and inlineCompletionPartialAccept in EditSources
- Include session ID in inline completion telemetry events
- Add new chatCompletionAccepted telemetry event for completions from chat
- Enhance InlineEditArcTelemetrySender to include session ID in telemetry

Addresses issues #265831 and #265829

This change improves telemetry tracking by including session IDs in completion events, enabling better analysis of user behavior across sessions.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a project in VSCode web connected to a VSCode server (in a container for instance) that contains `shell` tasks that run on "folderOpen"
2. Sometimes, tasks are run before the server reports the supported tasks type,
3. The `task` output reports: `Warning: shell tasks are unavailable in the current environment.`

title: Fix inappropriate use of error telemetry for activation status events
body:
This PR addresses the incorrect usage of error telemetry methods for non-error events in the Neural Edit Synthesis (NES) activation status tracking.

## Problem

The code was using `publicLogError2` to send activation status telemetry, which is inappropriate because:

- Error telemetry should only be used for actual errors, exceptions, and failures
- Activation status is feature insight telemetry, not error telemetry  
- This causes events to be incorrectly classified as errors in telemetry systems
- It can skew error metrics and misrepresent feature usage data

## Solution

Changed the telemetry method from `publicLogError2` to `publicLog2` in the activation status reporting:

```typescript
// Before (incorrect)
this.telemetryService.publicLogError2<NesActivationStatusEvent, NesActivationStatusClassification>('nesActivationStatus', {
    activated: true,
    timestamp: Date.now(),
    context: 'initialization'
});

// After (correct)  
this.telemetryService.publicLog2<NesActivationStatusEvent, NesActivationStatusClassification>('nesActivationStatus', {
    activated: true,
    timestamp: Date.now(),
    context: 'initialization'
});
```

## Validation

- **Security**: CodeQL analysis passed with no vulnerabilities
- **Patterns**: Follows existing VS Code telemetry patterns (similar to shell integration activation)
- **GDPR**: Maintains proper classification with `SystemMetaData` and `FeatureInsight`
- **Testing**: Added comprehensive test to ensure correct telemetry pipeline usage

The telemetry event properly uses `SystemMetaData` classification for GDPR compliance and `FeatureInsight` purpose for feature usage tracking, ensuring activation status data flows through the correct telemetry pipeline.

Fixes #265809.

title: Merge paths in code-workspace folders to create virtual folders
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

A structure like this:
```json
	"folders": [
		{
			"path": "."
		},
		{
			"path": "myproject/src/lib/tools",
			"name": "tools/md"
		},
		{
			"path": "myproject/static/tools",
			"name": "tools/images"
		},
	],
```
will currently result in this folder structure:
```
- myproject
  - project
    - structure
- tools/md
  - someContent
- tools/images
  - someContent
```

I would rather like this structure ("merged" virtual paths):
```
- myproject
  - project
    - structure
- tools
  - md
    - someContent
  - images
    - someContent
```

the workspace, in this case the workspace had 100k+ files

title: Add Option to Set Tree View as Default in Source Control Graph
body: Type: Feature Request VS Code's Source Control Graph view allows users to select between tree view and list view representations for history items via the ... menu, which is a great addition based on user demand. However, users who prefer the tree view have to manually switch it each time, which can be repetitive. It would be helpful to add a setting option to configure the tree view as the default representation, ensuring it persists across sessions.
